key_points: President Joe Biden signed the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021, initiating another round of stimulus checks.
Non-citizens who pay taxes as residents in the U.S. and hold a valid Social Security number are eligible for a stimulus payment.
Eligible non-citizens include lawful permanent residents and qualifying resident aliens.
Undocumented immigrants and those filing taxes with an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) are not eligible for the payment.
The American Rescue Plan includes mixed immigration status families for stimulus checks, a change from the CARES Act policy.
Lawful permanent residents, qualifying resident aliens, DACA participants, TPS individuals, and H1-B visa holders with Social Security numbers are eligible.
Nonresident aliens, foreign government-related individuals, teachers/trainees, foreign students, and professional athletes typically do not qualify.
U.S. citizens living abroad are also eligible for a stimulus check provided they meet certain criteria.
Eligible recipients abroad will receive payments via direct deposit or paper check based on the information on file with the IRS.
Individuals who didn't receive the first two stimulus checks can claim them through the Recovery Rebate Credit on their 2020 taxes.
